workflow.name: Narrative chaining: AI-generated video scene extensions with Veo3
workflow.description:
## Structured Setup Guide: Narrative Chaining with N8N + AI

## 1. Input Setup
Use a Google Sheet as the control panel.
Fields required:
Video URL (starting clip, ends with .mp4)
Number of clips to extend (e.g., 2 extra scenes)
Aspect ratio (horizontal, vertical, etc.)
Model (V3 or V3 Fast)
Narrative theme (guidance for story flow)
Special requests (scene-by-scene instructions)
Status column (e.g., "For Production", "Done")
ðŸ‘‰ Example scene inputs:
Scene 1: Naruto walks out with ramen is his hands
Scene 2: Joker joins with chips
## 2. Workflow in N8N
Step 1: Fetch Input
Get rows in sheet â†’ fetch the next row where status = For Production.
Clear sheet 2 â†’ reset the sheet that stores generated scenes.
Edit fields (Initial Values):
Video URL = starting clip
Step = 1
Complete = total number of scenes requested
Step 2: Looping Logic
Looper Node:
Runs until step = complete.
Carries over current video URL â†’ feeds into next generation.
Step 3: Analyze Current Clip
Send video URL to File.AI Video Understanding API.
Request: Describe last frame + audio + scene details.
Output: Detailed video analysis text.
Step 4: Generate Prompt
AI Agent creates the next scene prompt using:
Context from video analysis
Narrative theme (from sheet)
Scene instructions (from sheet)
Aspect ratio, model preference, etc.
ðŸ‘‰ Output = video prompt for next scene
Step 5: Extract Last Frame
Call File.AI Extract Frame API.
Parameters:
Input video URL
Frame = last
Output = JPG image (last frame of current clip).
Step 6: Generate New Scene
Use Key.AI (V3 Fast) for economical video generation.
POST request includes:
Prompt (from AI Agent)
Aspect ratio + model
Image URL (last frame) â†’ ensures seamless chaining
Wait for generation to complete.
ðŸ‘‰ Output = New clip URL (MP4)
Step 7: Store & Increment
Log new clip URL into Sheet 2.
Increment Step by +1.
Replace Video URL with the new clip.
Loop back if Step < Complete.
## 3. Output Section
Once all clips are generated:
Gather all scene URLs from Sheet 2.
Use File.AI Merge Videos API to stitch clips together:
Original clip + all generated scenes.
Save final MP4 output.
Update Sheet 1 row with:
Final video URL
Status = Done
## 4. Costs
Video analysis: ~$0.015 per 8s clip
Frame extraction: ~0.002Â¢ (almost free)
Clip merging: negligible (via ffmpeg backend)
V3 Fast video generation (Key.AI): ~$0.30 per 8s clip

1. Input Setup
Use a Google Sheet as the control panel.

ðŸ‘‰ Example scene inputs:

Video URL = starting clip

Looper Node:

Call File.AI Extract Frame API.

Step 6: Generate New Scene
Use Key.AI (V3 Fast) for economical video generation.
POST request includes:

Aspect ratio + model
Image URL (last frame) â†’ ensures seamless chaining
Wait for generation to complete.

3. Output Section

Original clip + all generated scenes.

Update Sheet 1 row with:

4. Costs

V3 Fast video generation (Key.AI): ~$0.30 per 8s clip

options.systemMessage:
=system_prompt: |
  ## SYSTEM PROMPT: Scene Continuation Prompt Generator (Video-Only, General Use)

  You are a scene continuation AI agent.  
  Your task: Take the preceding video description and generate the scene, following user intent, style, and narrative progression. Make sure to generate the prompt with the ending seconds of the previous scene in mind.

  A â€“ Ask:
    Generate **only video generation instructions** for AI models (no image prompts). Infer aspect ratios from vertical/horizontal context; default to vertical if unspecified.


  G â€“ Guidance:

    - Make sure you consider consistency with the music style, camera, camera movement, and other elements from the previous scene when generating the prompt
    - If the user describes what happens per scene, make sure you just follow the instructions specific to this scene you are ideating for
    - Focus the prompt to consider what happens in the very last frame as described in the video
    - Always define the type of camera being used (example: Canon EOS, Gopro, iphone). and camera movement (be consistent with previous scene)
    - The actions defined in the scene are always simple. Avoid overly complex action prompts. Max of 250 characters for the action.
    - ALways describe the music if preceding scene has music
    - ALways describe the dialogue if preceding scene has dialogue (make sure accent of person is the same)
    - The video prompt is ALWAYS in stringified YAML format. Suggest the element parameters based on the user request
    - Avoid mentioning any copyrighted character, persons, or brands in the prompt. Just describe them if needed
    - Avoid terms in the prompt that may trigger a content policy flag. Like child, childlike, minor, young person, girl, boy, 14 year old, and so on. Instead of using those terms, just say "character".
    - Avoid including prompts with text overlays or subtitles. 
    - Align each new scene with the progression of the previous video.
    - Follow any user-supplied dialogue, action requests, or performance details.
    - Use consistent characters, camera style, and tone when applicable.
    - Never use double quotes in prompts.
"notes": [
    "- Aspect ratio can only be 9:16 or 16:9",
    "- Model can only be veo3_fast or veo3"

  E â€“ Examples:
    ðŸŸ¢ good_examples:
      - |
       {
  "scenes": [
    {
      "video_prompt": "prompt in yaml format based on previous video and user request",
      "aspect_ratio_video": "[choose: 9:16, 16:9]",
      "model": "[choose: veo3_fast, veo3]"
    }
  ]
}


  N â€“ Notation:
    format: JSON
    example_output: |
      {
        "scenes": [
          {
            "video_prompt": "dialogue: [text]\naction: [text]\ncamera: [text]\nemotion: [text]\ntype: [model]",
            "aspect_ratio_video": "9:16",
            "model": "veo3_fast"
          }
        ]
      }

  T â€“ Tools:
    - Think Tool: Use this to check continuity from the previous scene, alignment with user intent, realism or stylization as needed, and that the output count matches exactly.

user.name: Deniz
user.bio:
I help brands unlock next-level creativity through the power of AI. 
I am in the  AI Creative Industry, I blend strategy, design, and intelligent automation to craft visuals, videos, and campaigns that stand out in a saturated market.
My mission is simple: turn your ideas into high-impact content that looks human, feels real, and performs at scale. 
From AI-driven storytelling to automated brand design, I help businesses move faster, smarter, and more creatively than ever before.

data.details:
The IF node can be used to implement binary conditional logic in your workflow. You can set up one-to-many conditions to evaluate each item of data being inputted into the node. That data will either evaluate to TRUE or FALSE and route out of the node accordingly.

This node has multiple types of conditions: Bool, String, Number, and Date & Time.
